title: How to Get an Autograph at a Baseball Game

steps.headline: Try to get seats up front close to the field but not behind the net.
steps.description: You should also get up front during batting practice or warm-ups. Players will sign items before the game with generosity.

steps.headline: Observe where the players stand, wait, or offer autographs at games.
steps.description: You may not be able to get the autograph during the game but can try to catch a player after the game, before the game during warm ups or post game near the player exit.

steps.headline: Visit home games regularly and determine the best place to sit to have player interaction and the chance for an autograph.
Have a quality photo, licensed merchandise, or licensed product available for the athlete to sign and the pen ready to go.
steps.description: Keep a pen which is permanent and won't bleed or discolor for them to use. Check hobby stores or memorabilia stores for a pen that is ideal for collecting quality autographs. Bring a quality photograph from home or use a photo sold by the gift shop.

steps.headline: Understand you may not be able to get the attention of one of the top players in the game, but his teammates may be more accessible.
Ask the player nicely for an autograph.
steps.description: Depending on how the day is going you may get a "yes" or "no". Players appreciate respect because they've got dozens of fans yelling at them all at once. They'll be more inclined to sign if you call out to them using their name. And using the proper term of respect such as "Mr Guerrero" rather than "Vladdy" will give you much more success. Don't take rejection personally. They may just not be in the mood for it at the particular game you're attending. Try again the next game, perhaps he will remember you, and give in. Be polite, even if they tell you "no;" there's always next time.

steps.headline: Ask if they have time to pose for a photograph if you have a friend and camera ready.
steps.description: Then you can bring the photo back for an autograph.

steps.headline: Compliment the player on a game well played, a good season, etc.
steps.description: Tell him how much you love the team, how many games you've been to.

steps.headline: Try to be conversational but not super chatty.
steps.description: Be friendly and don't ask tabloid type questions about the team or their personal life. They will likely get offended.

tyn: Willingness to accept what you get

Then you can bring the photo back for an autograph. Compliment the player on a game well played, a good season, etc. Tell him how much you love the team, how many games you've been to. Try to be conversational but not super chatty. Be friendly and don't ask tabloid type questions about the team or their personal life. They will likely get offended.
